Agreeably to the provisions of Sec. 3, Art. Ill, p. 492, compiled statute's, I have caused to be prepared the statements therein specified, in detail, as is shown by the books on file in this ofiice ; also in conformity thereto, I submit the following recommendations and views as to the support of the public credit, lessening the public expenses, using the public money to the best advantage, etc. :
The bonded indebtedness of the state is 8499,267.35. $50,000 of this amount, commonly known as "grasshopper bonds," falls due March 1st, 1885. The accumulation of "sinking fund" between now and then will be ample to pay them when due. $449,267-35, known as "funding bonds, "" will not be due before
April 1, 1897—8123,000 of this amount is held by private parties in Xew York, and the balance is held by the "State Permanent
School fund " as an investment. As the Sinking Fund accumu
irer and the combined efforts of the county treasurers in col-
ections for, and payments 'to the State, we have successfully
athered the storm. Xew buildin Capitol Wing, Insti-

In concluding the statement portion of ray report I desire to note the amount of fees received in ray official capacity, and the
source from whence derived ;

ates these bonds will be redeemed, if the Legislature so elects.
Paxes are being collected more closelv than they have ever been
before. An effort was made by county treasurers to collect
delinquencies, which has universally been successful. The two
mill General Fund tax of 1880 has crippled our nuances to an
sxtent, but through the careful management of our Starr T:
tiitf for Deaf and Dumb, etc., were being erected and payments necessarily large, and all were paid from the General Fund, but as the storm hat passed, I believe we will not be seriously inconvenienced in the future, unless the Legislature in their lom, should appropriate for various purposes, sums to an :it greater than can be realized by a four or five mill lew.
The Board created for the purpose " to provide for the safe keeping of moneys belonging to the State." as per act approved February 24th, 1879, has met various times since November 30, 1880, and at no time has money been found in the Treasury in excess of $100,000 as prescribed by law, consequently no investments have been made. On the 19th of October, 1882, the Board met and the State Treasurer reported as by law directed. It was decided that the U. S. four per cent, bonds, amounting to $50,000, heretofore purchased by direction of the Board, be sold to the best possible advantage, for the purpose of sustaining the public credit and meeting the current demands which will necessarily be made upon the Treasury. The State Treasurer was empowered to sell the same. October 23, 1882 the returns from the sale of said bonds were placed to the credit of the State,
tiiiL r 27 per cent, on the investment, or a little less than nine r cent, per annum.

SCHOOL LAND FUND
Thii office has considerable difficulty with the county treasurers in tlfixiliiifl ¦ settlement with this fund. Our check against a county treasurer is the duplicate receipt he issues, which the provides shall be sent to this office by the county clerk.
Sometimes this is not done but i
nt elsewhere, contrary to law.
tasionally it is carried away by ost, all of which causes innum
the payee, sometimes mislaid rable letter's from this depart-
ment tracing the matter
I would recommend as I have
heretofore done, that the law
be so amended as to oblige the county treasurer to periodically (say monthly), make a statement of all receipts issued, giving date, number, name description and amount, and forward the same to this office accompanied by the receipts issued, (dnplica
It an examination and attesting of the same by the county rk. This I think will straighten the matter. The business this fund is increasing and it should work harmoniously.
HOSPITAL FOR I.VSANi
Efour attention is respectfully directed to statement No. 18 ich shows the amount of $110,844.03 due the State from the ious counties for the -upport of their respective insane. This
amount will be partly collected, tint a large portion of the amount will remain passive without an effort to collect, which I deem to be wrong and unjust. Some counties claim that they have no right or power to levy the tax, which will increase the rate of taxation prescribed by law. Legislation is needed to obviate this difficulty. The hospital is almost self-sustaining. This fund has already enlarged the building four wings at a cost of 869,000, and there is in the treasury of the State unexpended $35,673.84. The amount due, if collected, added to the amouut
152
153
AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS.
unexpended at this date, will be sufficient to run the institution a few years, or increase the size of the building to accommodate the growing attendance of that unfortunate class of people, for five years or more to come.
It often arises that a county, after the State renders an account for keeping its insane, disputes the place of residence of one or more of its patients, and declines the payment of the State ac-
>unt. I would recommend that the law be so amended that in
the case of a dispute a board be appointed for the purpose ot fixing the residence.
